questions.text: The anterior pituitary is composed of secretory cellslike somatotrope, lactotrope, thyrotrope and corticotrope. Which of the following hormones is secreted by gonadotropes?

Cell Type Hormones Secreted Percentage of Total secretory Cells
Somatotrope Growth hormone 50
Lactotrope Prolactin 10-30
Corticotrope ACTH 10
Thyrotrope TSH 5
Gonadotrope FSH, LH 20

questions.text: A 19-year-old man sustained internal injury in the abdomen after a road accident. Which of the following features are not present if there is injury to fibres of Nervus erigentes? Ejaculation Erection Sweating Defecation

Charcot Marie Tooth Disease is a peripheral neuropathy which leads to progressive muscle weakness typically noticeable in adolescence or early adulthood. In this disease longer nerves are affected first, symptoms usually begin in the feet and lower legs and then can affect the fingers, hands, and arms. Which among the following defective connexin causes the disease?

A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency after an accident. On examination his left foot is hanging, and he is not able to extend his toe and do inversion but eversion is normal. There is also loss of sensations between 1st and 2nd toe. Which of the following nerves has been injured?
In which if the following disorder, ATP 7A protein is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Menke’e Disease Wilson’s disease
  • Cu Deficiency
  • Cu Excess
  • ATP-7A protein defective
  • ATP-7B protein defective
  • X-linked recessive
  • Autosomal recessive
  • ATP-7A is present in intestine for absorption of Cu. Its deficiency causes:
    • ↓ Cu (Cu stays in intestinal cell, unable to enter blood)
    • ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) (due to insufficient Cu to form cp)
  • ATP-7B is present in liver to throw Cu in bile and also incorporates Cu incp. Its deficiency causes:
    • ↑ Cu in liver (due to non-excretion from body)
    • ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) (due to non-incorporation of Cu in cp)

A 4 years old child was born at term with no congenital abnormalities. He is now 70% normal body weight. On examination, dependent edema in lower extermities and large distended abdomen is found. Which of the following nutritional problems is most likely present in the child?
questions.explanation:
Kwashiorkor Marasmus
  • In preschool children (1-5 years)
  • Due to low protein intake
  • Protruding abdomen (due to ascites) and subcutaneous fat reserved
  • Poor appetite
  • No skin changes
  • Peripheral oedema present (lower legs, lower arms and face)
  • Thin and brittle hair
  • Moon facies
  • Mild growth retardation
  • In infants (<1 years)
  • Due to low calorie intake
  • Prominent ribs
  • Good appetite
  • Pigmeneted and flaky skin
  • Peripheral odema not present
  • Thin and brittle hair
  • Old man like facies
  • Severe growth retardation

options.label: A

options.label: B

- Seen in Tb

- Langhans cell - Normal
Foreign body GC

- Seen with sutures & talc
Warthin-Finkeldey GC

- Seen in measles
Reed-Sternberg cell/ Tumor Gaint cell

- Owl-eye appearance

- Seen in Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Touton Cell

- Fat droplets

- Seen in Xanthama

questions.text: A 27-year-old female brought her 6-month-old baby with complaint of poor feeding and slow responsiveness. On checking anthropometric parameters doctor found out that baby is malnourished. At what age does the weight of baby triples?
If a husband or relatives of the husband of a women subject the female to cruelty shall be punished with 3 years’ imprisonment and also liable to fine under
In which of the following autopsy techniques all the organs (Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs) are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
questions.explanation:
Autopsy Techniques Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed"en masse," as one big organ block. The best technique to see relations amongst organs.Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other Difficult to handle large mass.
Ghon’s Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks(en block) This method can also be used in Infants
Virchow’s Organs are removedone by one Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situdissection (inside the body itself) Good for infected bodies (prevents spreading of infection)

questions.text: A 35Y/O male is on medication for GERD for 2 months , but condition is not improving , on endoscopic examination Barrett’s esophagus is diagnosed , which of the following statement is right regarding the given condition?

A 60y/o male died of myocardial infarction 8 hours ago, to study the pathological changes, cut section of heart was sent for staining with TTC (triphenyl tetrazolium chloride). What will be the interpretation of the test n the basis of pathological changes?

options.label: A
options.text: The necrotic/infarct part stains pale /yellow, because of loss of dehydrogenase.

options.label: B
options.text: The normal heart part stains brick red because of loss of dehydrogenase enzyme

options.label: C
options.text: The necrotic part stains brick red because it retains dehydrogenase enzyme.

options.label: D
options.text: The normal heart stains yellow/pale because of loss of dehydrogenase enzyme.

questions.correct_answer: A. The necrotic/infarct part stains pale /yellow, because of loss of dehydrogenase.

Bipolar
Prevention of Mania Prevention of Depression
  • Lithium (DOC for mania prophylaxis)
  • Anti – epileptic drugs
    • Carbamazepine
    • Valproate (DOC for rapid cyclers)
    • Topiramate
  • Anti – psychotics

1. Lithium (DOC for prevention of depression)

  • It is the only drug that decrease suicidal risk in bipolar patients

2. Lamotrigine

questions.text: A man who suffered an attack of stroke was brought to emergency he had a history of urine turning black. On thorough testing it was concluded that patient has a low NAP score and CD55 deficiency. What drug therapy will be given in such patient?

12 y/o child was brought with chief complaints of bone pain in lower end of femur mainly during night-time which is relieved by taking aspirin. x ray findings of the condition are as given below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: NSAIDS and radio frequency ablation or excision

questions.correct_answer: A. NSAIDS and radio frequency ablation or excision

questions.text: A patient presented with vesicular lesions over single dermatome over chest, he also complains of pain what is the diagnosis?
A patient came to the ER with complaint of muscle cramps and weakness. On blood examination hypokalaemia was noted. Which of the following ECG findings will be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolonged QT interval with flat T-waves

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased QT interval with tall T-waves

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased PR interval with ST depression

options.label: D
options.text: Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation

questions.correct_answer: A. Prolonged QT interval with flat T-waves

questions.text: Surgical resection is carried out in 68-year woman with uterine cancer. This cancer can spread directly to labia majora in lymphatics that follow which of the following structures?
questions.correct_answer: D. Round ligament of the uterus

questions.text: An 8 years old child is presented with short stature, obesity, bowing of legs and trident hands. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
Ebb and flow are two phases of metabolic response to injury. Pick the odd statement.

options.label: A
options.text: Ebb phase lasts for 10days and is known as energy consuming phase.

options.label: B
options.text: In flow phase insulin thyroid hormone and growth hormones increases.

options.label: C
options.text: In catabolic part of flow phase there is negative nitrogen balance

options.label: D
options.text: In ebb phase BMR, thyroid hormone, body temperature, all decreases.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ebb phase lasts for 10days and is known as energy consuming phase.
questions.explanation:
PHASE ROLE PHYSIOLOGY
EBB(<24hours) Maintain blood volume and catecholamines. Decreased BMR and O2 consumption, low thyroid and low insulin
Flow
1. Catabolic phase(3-10days Maintain energy Increase BMR and O2 consumption. Negative nitrogen balance
2. Anabolic phase Replacement of damaged tissue Growth hormones and insulin increase. Positive nitrogen balance.

questions.text: A young female, with a 28-day regular cycle, is your patient. If she comes to your clinic today and mentions that it is the first day of her usually ‘5-days’ long menses, and insists that she is interested in bearing a child, you mention a window to her to maximise chances of getting pregnant. This revolves around the fact that the sperm, on average, remains fertile in the female genital tract for:
Which of the following are components of the definitive chorion?

options.label: D
options.text: Extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast

questions.correct_answer: D. Extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents at 10 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of epilepsy on anticonvulsant therapy. Which of the following is true about pharmacotherapy of this patient in pregnancy?

options.label: B
options.text: Therapeutic drug monitoring is not required

options.label: C
options.text: Folic acid supplementation prevents risk of NTD in these patients

options.label: D
options.text: Lamotrigine is the most teratogenic drug.

questions.correct_answer: C. Folic acid supplementation prevents risk of NTD in these patients

orange 16

options.label: B

questions.text: Which of the following are bad prognostic factor in a patient with Schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: Early onset, female sex, catatonic type

options.label: C
options.text: Acute onset, catatonic type, male sex

options.label: D
options.text: History of mood disorder in the family

questions.explanation:
Good Prognosis Bad Prognosis
Acute onset (<2 weeks) Insidious onset
Advanced age at onset (>35 year) Early onset <20 year)
Catatonic subtype (Paranoid subtype has an intermediate prognosis) Simple, disorganized, hebephrenic
Female Sex Male Sex
Prominent Positive Symptom Prominent Negative symptom, aggressive symptoms
Presence of affective symptom Absence of affective symptoms
Family H/O mood disorder Family h/o Schizophrenia
Good premorbid functioning and personality traits Poor premorbid functioning and personality traits

questions.text: A newborn was presented with defect in abdominal wall as shown in picture. Pick the odd statement regarding this condition.

questions.text: A patient came to the ER with complaint of bloody urine and swelling in hands and feet. He also gave the history that he must get up at night a lot to urinate. On immunofluorescence - IgA, IgG, IgM, C1q, C3 all deposited in subepithelial and subendothelial was seen. What is the diagnosis?
A rose gardener following prick injury develops the skin changes. What is the causative agent?

A 19-year-old female, came to your clinic with a complaint of not having menses even once. You notice that she has normal secondary sexual development, and order for an ultrasound. It reveals that there is an absence of uterus and upper part of vagina, while lower 2/3rd of vagina is still present. You begin to consider MRKH syndrome and explain to patient that the lower part of vagina is present since it develops separate from the rest, from the:-
Which of the following is not a selective shunt surgery for portal vain hypertension?
questions.correct_answer: A. Side to side portocaval shunt

questions.text: A 3 year old girl child was brought to anganwaadi and her mother complains that she doesn’t eat and is less active and her height is less than other children of her age. On examination her height is 84 cm. what should be the expected height of this child?

A 50-year-old HIV positive individual presented with a 6 week history of 6 watery bowel movements per day. His routine stool examination results had been negative. The patient has reported a weight loss of 4 kg since the onset of diarrhoea. What do you think is the most common cause of diarrhoea in this patient?

A microscopic examination shows clue cells. Which one of the following is the best drug of choice for treatment of this patient?

Colonoscopy of a patient was done. Saw tooth pattern was seen on it. What is the diagnosis of this condition?

A 37-year-old woman is complaining of a bearing-down sensation in her womb and an increased frequency of and burning sensation on urination. A 70-year-old female came to OPD with complaint of recurrent Herpes labialis and enlarged lymph nodes. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and non-blanching petechiae around then knee was seen. The image given below was seen on peripheral smear. On what medication will you start the patient?

A 45-year-old male who is a known case of HIV presented to the Emergency with complaint of fever, nuchal rigidity, headache and photophobia. The organism was isolated when Indian ink test was performed on the CSF sample taken through Lumbar puncture. What is the organism implicated in such case?
A 33-year-old woman presents at 24 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following drugs, for the management of DCMP should be avoided in this patient?
Which of the following is/are a cause of non- communicating hydrocephalus? Vein of Galen malformation Choroid plexus papilloma Arnold Chiari malformation Meningeal metastasis
questions.explanation:
COMMUNICATING HYDROCEPHALUS NON-COMMUNICATING HYDROCEPHALUS

[ Mnemonic - CAMP]

  • C - Choroid plexus papilloma
  • A - Achondroplasia
  • M - Meningeal malignancy or metastasis
  • P - Post hemorrhagic

[Mnemonic - MAAAD HIV]

  • M - Mass lesion (ICSOL)
  • A - Abscess
  • A - Aqueductal stenosis
  • A - Arnold Chiari malformation
  • D - Dandy-Walker malformations
  • H - Hematoma
  • I - Infections (Toxoplasma, mumps, Neurocysticercosis)
  • V - Vein of Galen malformations

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the Retro cochlear hearing loss? Speech discrimination score is 60-80% Tone decay test is +ve SISI test is +ve BERA Wave V latency is <4.2 msec

TEST COCHLEAR RETROCOCHLEAR
Speech audiometry(SDS) 60-80% <40% Roll over phenomenon
Tone decay -ve +ve (>25dB)
SISI +ve -ve
ABLB Converging Diverging
BERA Wave V Latency Less than or equal to 4.2msec >4.2msec

questions.text: What is the common site of Boerhaave syndrome?
Identify the splint and for what purpose it is used for?

options.label: A
options.text: Bohler-brawn splint used for immobilization of lower limb

options.text: Thomas splint used for immobilization of upper limb

questions.correct_answer: A. Bohler-brawn splint used for immobilization of lower limb
questions.explanation:
BOHLER – BRAUN SPLINT

  • Fracture femur, Knee and tibia
  • 3 pulley mechanism

Proximal – to prevent foot drop.

2nd pulley – traction in line with the femur

3rd pulley – traction in line with the leg.

questions.text: Most common malignancy that metastasizes to the spine in females is:
questions.explanation:
Most common sites of primary for bone metastasis.
  1. In males – Prostate > Lung
  2. In Female – Breast > Lung
  3. In Children – Neuroblastoma
  4. Overall most common is breast
Skeletal sites most frequently involved
  1. Spine (Dorsal)
Lytic expansile metastasis seen in
  1. Renal cancer
  2. Thyroid carcinomas
Purely Osteoblastic secondaries
  1. Prostate/Carcinoid/Medulloblastoma

questions.text: Leber cells are most commonly seen in which of the following condition?

A 49-year-old woman has a large mass on the pelvic brim. Which of the following structures is most likely compressed by this mass when crossing the pelvic brim?
Which statement is wrong regarding damage control surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Phase 1 is identification od patient in Emergency room

options.label: B
options.text: Phase 3 is to correct lethal triad(coagulopathy, acidosis, hypothermia) in OT.

options.label: C
options.text: Phase 1 is to prevent contamination and control bleeding

options.label: D
options.text: Phase 2 is to correct lethal triad .

questions.correct_answer: A. Phase 1 is identification od patient in Emergency room
questions.explanation:
Phase I (initial exploration) Phase II (20 resuscitation) Phase III (Definitive operation)
  • Initial exploration

↓

  • For rapid control of hemorrhage + contamination
  • Packing of 4 Quadrants
  • For perforation

↓

Suture closure

↓

Segmental Stapled resection
  • Shift the pt. to ICU

↓

  • For 2 resuscitation
    • 48 hrs
    • Correct hypothermia, coagulopathy & metabolic acidosis
  • Planned re-exploration
  • Definitive repair of injuries
